and now we have a version of the Fried Liver Attack! Let me quote from Wikipedia "The Fried Liver Attack also called the Fegatello Attack (named for an Italian idiom meaning "dead as a piece of liver") is a chess opening. This colourfully named opening is a variation of the Two Knights Defence in which White sacrifices a knight for a superficially impressive attack on the enemy king. The Fried Liver has been known for many centuries the first known game score being from a game played in Rome in 1610.[1]. The Fried Liver Attack is classified in the Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings (ECO) with the code C57.

After usual opening moves of the Two Knights (1.e4 e5 2.Nf3 Nc6 3.Bc4 Nf6) White goes on the offensive the game continuing 4.Ng5 d5 5.exd5 Nxd5. This latter move gives White a strong attack and is often considered to be a mistake. (Black usually plays 5...Na5 instead; other moves are 5...Nd4 and 5...b5.) White can now get a small advantage with 6.d4 (the Lolli Attack).
However The Fried Liver Attack involves a far more speculative knight sacrifice on f7 with the defining moves 6.Nxf7 Kxf7"
The above mentioned Lolli Attack often leads into a delayed version of this gambit - (Quoting from "Openings for the Club Player by Tim Harding and Leonard Barden" 6.... The Exchange Variation of the French Defence. This leads to a symmetrical drawish position and White's only advantage is to have the first move. The Exchange French is often played by weaker players trying to get a draw against a stronger player not the other way round!

?! The Svenonius Variation. Not popular in GK's database and statistics give Black an edge. This is a solid move but removes the best developing square for White's queenside knight. If I were going to move that pawn I would play 4.c4 forming a quasi-Queen's Gambit position but obviously no longer a gambit as it is defended by the bishop. Very interesting and unusual. White opts to move his king and lose castling rights instead of more naturally blocking with Qe2 or Be3 both of which the DB suggests. I suppose that after 7.Qd2 Qxd2 8.Bxd2 White's light-squared bishop is not on such a good square while White's dark-squared bishop is probably not very well placed on e3. At any rate White's king is now blocking any development of White's dark-squared bishop and preventing White's knight from developing onto any square other than a3 so I would definitely go for blocking the check in White's position.

Part of me - the adventurous attacking part - wanted to play 7...Bf4  forcing the White's king onto c2. But after 7.Kc2 (1) I have no more attack; (2) my dark-squared bishop is under attack by his dark-squared bishop and I have to either waste a move fleeing or exchange a developed for an undeveloped bishop; (3) his king is blocking his own development on d2 so I have no reason to want to force it off. Three good reasons for not playing that move. I decided against it and went for the more flexible and calm 7...O-O.
On second thoughts maybe 8...Qd7 would have been stronger.

Both sides have poor queenside development but there is a crucial difference: Black can develop his queenside at will although I have not yet done so; White has a cramped queenside whose development is blocked by his king and c-pawn.
My opponent makes the logical and correct decision. He moves his king to a safer square and opens up a line for the development of his dark-squared bishop.
I am anxious to exchange pieces before my opponent can develop. If I can exchange off all his active pieces his lag in development will be much harder to cope with.

An aggressive strike perhaps premature with Black's development lagging.
White must of course take; otherwise the pawn comes to e4.
I jump at the chance to exchange off Black's fianchettoed bishop leaving his king somewhat exposed.

Here I made a strategic decision that determined the course of the rest of the game. Black must recapture with the pawn so he will have an isolated queen's pawn (isolani) but it will also be a passed pawn. While White tries to attack this pawn Black will be trying to promote it. Is its weakness greater than its strength?
The first offensive is launched. The bishop cannot be taken while the queen is undefended.

White has formed a Barcza formation on the kingside; Black has a classic centre-based position with his pawns and knights controlling the centre.
Now finally White opens out and takes on a more dynamic position with a strike at the centre.

Left to myself I would have played 6...d4 but GameKnot's DB showed that this pawn advance is premature and collapses after 7.c3 so I went for what the database showed was a more popular option i.e. to castle kingside.
I can't see why he did this move: it is counter-developing and very passive. Na3 would fulfil the same purpose.
And back again.
Suddenly a new idea forms. Why don't I build up pressure on White's pinned knight piling more pieces on until the attackters outnumber the defenders and I win the pinned piece!

The beauty of this is that while the knight is pinned to the queen the queen is tied to the knight's defence so it cannot move to liberate the knight! A vicious circle culminating in the fact that none of the two pieces can move. A worthy prize in itself but I was after more...I wanted to WIN the knight.
Only one problem obstructs my cunning plan. The attackers unfortunately do not outnumber the defenders.
Fine then. Mass exchanges and the material count is still equal.
Excellent! A rooks-and-pawns endgame. I love the endless complexity in their apparent simplicity and the immense capacity for any side to make a tiny positional slip which costs the game.
Both rooks to the semi-open central files but I think the d-file offers greater opportunities for Black than the e-file does for White.

The queenside pawn formation looks suspiciously like a very well-known endgame pawn promotion puzzle. But since the rooks are on the board the best that I can expect of these pawns is to be exchanged off.
Off goes one pair of rooks.
Initiating the pawn exchanges.
BAM! BAM! BAM! and all the queenside pawns have disappeared. Now the battle focuses on the kingside...where the position looks drawn.
Aha! I saw the light! I could threaten checkmate after 37...Rh7  ! Maybe my opponent hasn't noticed! In any case there was only one feasible move that he could defend with...
...and unfortunately he found it.
Closing the kingside pawn formation again. I have gained a slim advantage in the form of a pawn but I very much doubt that I was able to convert it into a win.
A draw was agreed. Should it have been a draw? What do you think? Are there any wins in sight? I very much doubt it :-).

A little interlude to the Grand Tour match of fatcat2 vs Computers. Having played 4 games so far against various computers I am beginning to feel that I'm missing something. What I need is a good example of how to beat my silicon opponents - and what better one to look at than the 1st game of the 1997 match of Garry Kasparov vs the updated Deep Blue?

We start with the Reti Opening. Quite a recent one and a flexible opening as it offers opportunities to transpose into King Pawn Queen Pawn or English setups.
White is going for a Barcza kingside formation.
The Keres Variation.
White has a solid although possibly slightly cramped position. Notice the excellent control that his fianchettoed bishops have of the centre.

White is slowly solidly gaining more space and advancing his pawns and pieces. The game has so far been very positional; I have seen no tactics coming into it which is unlike Kasparov but I suppose a good policy against a computer.
Now White is becoming more dynamic with a strike at the centre and opening up his position.
White appears to be retreating! He has formed a solid but cramped kingside. Have I missed something?

If I did not yet know the result of the game I would say White is in a lot of trouble. Deep Blue is playing to the traditional strengths of a computer - tactical attacks -  while White seems to be forced into passivity.
Keeping the queenside files blocked.
White is bypassing all of White's pawns rather than capturing them and thus maintaining the positional equilibrium and not allowing Black any open lines to attack down.
Suddenly it is Black who appears to be on the ropes! His kingside has been cracked open like an egg and White's kingside pawns are menacing his position...
White is maintaining his strong position on the kingside.
Such mass exchanges can only help White who is down by an exchange but has an easily won pawn formation.
Deep Blue resigns. The final result of the match incidentally was 3.5-2.5 to Deep Blue...this was the only game Kasparov won. But I am going to study it further and I hope to pick up some tips...
